intro: Loudonia aurea var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaved goldcup, is a perennial herb native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and in wetlands. The plant features narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces clusters of bright yellow flowers in late spring. Its botanical structure includes a fibrous root system and a branched stem. It is often found in wetland ecosystems and is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological role.
